1.title: Sourcing Grasses from Dhungalla
1.description: Taken in the breadth intensive 'Ancient and Contemporary Indigenous Arts 2' led by the Wilin Centre for Indigenous Arts and Cultural Development in early February 2020 on Yorta Yorta country. These students accessed creative cultural practices, many thousands of years in the making. The class environment acted as a space for renewed commitment to reconciliation, with a simmering optimism for the future by understanding how we are all in this together.

2.title: Smoking Ceremony
2.description: Taken by VCA Director at the Smoking Ceremony as part of National Reconciliation Week in 2019. The artist (pictured) reflects on the way the smoke had completely enveloped and transported them.

3.title: The Road is Far
3.format: acrylic on canvas and digital painting
3.description: This work is an abstract representation of the way hundreds of people create one soul. It is not about our differences, but more about our common goals. The outlines represent the vulnerability of our hidden personalities and the gradient colours share the inner power that fills everybody’s souls, breaking down the barriers of complexity to that of a simpler merging.

4.title: Queensbury, VIC
4.format: mixed natural, recycled and adhesive media collage and digital collage
4.description: This work is a collage of multiple artworks created over the years by educators and children of Queensbury Children's Centre (QCC). Bunjil is strongly featured in this to acknowledge and celebrate the wedge-tailed eagle as the creator and protector of Wurundjeri land, where they live, work, learn and play. Over the past several years, educators at QCC have focused on gaining, sharing and embedding Indigenous perspectives into teaching practices.

5.title: Loving, kindness and surrounding
5.description: This work is an expression of the hardships shared in a journey together. A reminder to protect, learn and be kind to one another, not only to people, but also to surroundings and cultures.This work is an expression of the hardships shared in a journey together. A reminder to protect, learn and be kind to one another, not only to people, but also to surroundings and cultures.

6.title: Mist and Shadow
6.description: This image was taken during COVID-19 lockdown. The artist had been walking in their local area more than ever before. They came across signage indicating the life story of the river that had become their refuge, walking guide, entertainment and home during lockdown. That evening, Birrarung appeared – more than ever – to be a waterway of mist and shadow. It's long history in time juxtaposed against the young Melbourne city skyline. The artist expresses great comfort in knowing the country, the rivers and the people in their local area have been and will continue to be in this together.

7.title: Learning Weaving from an Elder
7.description: Taken in the breadth intensive 'Ancient and Contemporary Indigenous Arts 2' led by the Wilin Centre for Indigenous Arts and Cultural Development in early February 2020 on Yorta Yorta country. These students accessed creative cultural practices, many thousands of years in the making. The class environment acted as a space for renewed commitment to reconciliation, with a simmering optimism for the future by understanding how we are all in this together.

8.title: One
8.format: digital print made from an aquatint
8.description: From a series made to commemorate National Reconciliation Week 2020. Recycled materials from an aquatint made in 2010 when the artist began immigration to Australia. Inspired by the Dreamtime and the visual musical language of circles and dot art as an Indigenous Australian expression of spirit, country, water and the land. Layering communicates the many steps that have been taken by the community together so far. The artist conveys intricate interweaving colours overlapping and revealing through one another, like the sky at night that also became the morning sky when seen from an inverted angle as the piece may be viewed and displayed from all sides.

9.title: Untitled
9.description: This work uses the mixing of primary colours to indicate that we must all join together to move forward. The feet and hands are body parts that no matter who we are, we all possess the same human form, that we are all one and the same.
